texts.en: Bou N. is 39 years old and lives in the Kampong Cham with her husband and four of her children. She and her husband are farmers who are able to make a living of US$4 of profit every day. Two of the children are in school and two are garment factory workers. Bou N. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase farmland to expand her cultivation.

loans.use: To purchase farmland to expand her cultivation.

loans.name: Sayed Qasem

texts.en:
This man is S. Qasem the son of S. B.. He is 38 years old and is married with five children. He lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan.

S. Qasem has a general store and with the income he receives he supports all his family members. He has been working as a shopkeeper since 2000.

S. Qasem has requested a loan of 50,000 Afghani to purchase more things for his shop to complete his inventory and progress his business. He is happy about being part of this loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy materials to complete his inventory

loans.name: Tha

texts.en: Tha N. is 29 years old and lives in Takeo province with her husband and two young children. She is a garment factory worker and is able to make about US$1.50 each day, while her husband, pictured here, has a business making rice wine. On average, he makes US$2 per day. Than N. is asking for a loan of US$1000 so that her husband can reinvest in rice wine business.

loans.use: Reinvest in rice wine business.

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase genge items and medicine for her Pharmacy in bulk

loans.name: Peng

texts.en:
Peng P., 35, is a true entrepreneur who has had a business selling sweet picker radish since 2002. She makes US$2 of profit per day. Her husband stays at home and makes picker for his wife for sale. Cambodian people like picker radish and normally they serve it with rice. To make picker radish, first they wash the fresh radish and slice into four pieces. It is then dried under the sunshine. They then collect the dry radish and keep it in a jar along with  much sugar and little of salt. Ten days later they have a very delicious picker radish. Peng P. would like a loan from Kiva of US$1000 to make picker radish for sale.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: Supplies to make picker radish.

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en: Catalina T. is from the village of Punta. She is 48 years old, is married, and has eight adult children. Catalina owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Catalina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Catalina is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Celita

texts.en:
Celita S. is from the village of  Kiburiao,  in Quezon Bukidnon. She is 41 years old. Celita is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Celita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Celita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Celita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Celita is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Celita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Procopio

texts.en:
Procopio E. is from the village of Pan-ay, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 79 years old, is married, and has five adult children.

Procopio owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over twenty years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Procopio joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase land on which to raise additional crops. This loan will be his first from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve fund for future emergencies.


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase land on which to raise additional crops

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more used clothes in bulk

loans.name: Estrellita

texts.en:
Estrellita C. is from the village of Locsoon in Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old. Estrellita is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Estrellita raises and sells pigs. Estrellita has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Estrellita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrellita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. She used her previous loan to purchase piglets that she raised and then sold. Estrellita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be Estrellita's 7th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy food and supplies for her pigs

loans.name: Anastacia

texts.en:
Anastacia C. lives in Carmen Annex in the city of Ozamiz. She is a 61-year-old widow with 3 adult children. 

Anastacia is a micro-entrepreneur who prepares and processes a Filipino delicacy known as “balut,” an egg dish that most Filipinos love to eat. She started this business in 1993 with an income of 4,500 PHP a month. She joined PMPC in 2006 to use the credit services for additional business capital. She has repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP with a good repayment record. 

Now she wants to borrow 7,000 PHP to purchase more eggs to sell. This will be her seventh loan from PMPC. In the future, she plans to open a sari-sari (variety) store and to have a wealthy life.

loans.use: To buy more eggs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more rice, wheat flour, salt sugar and beans in bulk for her business.

loans.name: Joaquin

texts.en:
Joaquin V. is from the village of Dela Paz. She is 40 years old. Joaquin is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Joaquin plants, harvests, and sells vegetables from her garden. She has been in business for over 8 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Joaquin joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Joaquin is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This  will be Joaquin's 9th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Latifa Asan Group

texts.en:
Latifa is the group leader of Latifa Asan group. There are two members in this group and each of them wants to progress their business and make it larger. They are requesting a group of loan 21,000 Afghani.

Latifa wants to take a loan for her husband who has a generator repair shop.

The other member, who is Qamar Gul, would like to take a loan for her tire repair shop.

They both are glad that they have this opportunity to progress and develop their businesses.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her husband's generator repair business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth C. is already 45 years old. She manages a snacks and food vending business and also sells some grocery items at her stall. Her weekly net income is Php500. Wanting to increase her income, she planned to have a loan of Php5,000 from KIVA lenders as additional working capital for her business.

Elizabeth is married to a driver named Romeo and they are blessed with six children namely: Sheila – 23 years of age, a plain housekeeper, Michael - 22 years of age, a security guard in Manila, Carla - 21 years of age, Melvin 18 years of age, a college student taking up Development Communication, Joboy 16 years of age, a senior high school student, and their youngest Mary Camille -7  years of age, a grade I student. 

They reside at Barangay Mozzozzin Norte, Sta.Maria Isabela. Elizabeth hopes that KIVA lenders will grant her loan to sustain her family needs and most especially for the continued productivity of her business.

loans.use: additional capital for her food vending business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more used clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Estelito

texts.en:
Estelito, 44 years old, has been raising hogs for almost five years now. His net income per week is Php 1,000. He has decided to ask for a loan from generous KIVA lenders amounting to Php 8,000 to purchase hog feed and young piglets to raise.

Estelito's wife is an Overseas Filipino Worker. They have two children: Aljon, 17, and Conrado, 15. They reside in the rural village of Calaocan, Cabatuan, Isabela. Estelito wants to help his wife support the education of their two boys, who are currently enrolled in high school and college level.

loans.use: To purchase hog feed and piglets.

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn T. is from the village of Banlag, Valencia City. She is 33 years old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Jenelyn owns and operates a business providing motorcycle services to local community members. Jenelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $125 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Jenelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jenelyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to invest in her business. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza G. is from the village of Pangabuan Tangub City. She is 45 years old. Riza is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Riza owns and operates a "sari-sari" (variety) store, selling different products for daily use and dry goods in the local community. Riza has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $71 a month from these activities.

In 2008, Riza joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Riza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Riza is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her child's tuition fees and for daily needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Chashma Salar Group

texts.en:
This is Chashma Salar group which has four female members. These women would like to progress and develop their businesses.

Afghan Gul is the group leader and she has a bakery business in her house. She has run this business since the Taliban regime when all women were confined at home and there were no jobs and schools for them. Now, with the loan, she wants to buy more materials for her business to bring a new change in her business and to make progress.

Zahera wants to receive a loan for her husband who has a general store. Her husband wants to buy more things which he needs for his business.

Sorai wants to take a loan for her carpet-weaving business. She wants to buy better materials for carpet weaving and wants to progress her business and be able to support all her family members.

Sakina wants to receive a loan for her tailoring business. She needs to buy a new sewing machine for her business because she has lots of problems with the old one when sewing. Besides that, she wants to hire a student to support him in her business and enlarge her business.

Freshta wants to receive a loan for her husband's taxi business which needs a new part.

So they have together requested a group loan of 50,000 Afghani and they would like to say Kiva is the best loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy more materials for her bakery business

loans.name: Minardo

texts.en:
Minandro is a responsible father to his three children and good husband to his wife.  His family resides in the village of Calamagui, San Pablo, Isabela, Cagayan.  They aim to improve their living conditions and to give their children a better future. He and his wife are helping one another to work hard to earn a living for their family.  

Minandro is a farmer. He tills their land and plants rice, corn and vegetables. Aside from farming, he also works as a tricycle driver in their village, and his wife is managing their hog raising business in their backyard. They earn an average income of about $178 a month which is used for their basic needs and to finance the schooling of their children.
 
The couple want to earn more to meet the family's needs.  In line with this, Minandro is applying for a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP 9,000 to be used for the maintenance of his tricycle and for the maintenance of his crops. He believes that this will be a great help for the improvement of their standard of living.

loans.use: additional capital for the maintenance of his tricycle and farm

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en:
Edgar is engaged in the manufacturing of different kinds of furniture. He produces chairs, tables, cabinets, beds and a lot more. He hopes to maintain and continuously improve his business. With enough capital, he hopes to expand his business to earn more income for his family.

He is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000 as additional capital to buy the needed materials for his business. He needs more wood in order to produce more furniture. He hopes that his 3rd cycle loan request will be approved.

Edgar is 45 years old. He lives together with his family in the village of Ballacong, Ilagan, Isabela. He and his wife, Elizabeth, have four children, all of whom are currently studying. As the head of the family, he is trying to provide for their needs, especially when it comes to their educational needs. He also wants them to have a good future. That’s why he does his best to send them all to school.

loans.use: To buy materials for his furniture making business

loans.name: Hilario

texts.en:
Hilario P. is from the village of Kiburiao, Quezon Bukidnon. He is 43 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Hilario owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Hilario has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately $338 a month from these activities.

In 1997, Hilario joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Hilario has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Hilario is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be his 16th loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora, together with her husband, is engaged in manufacturing furniture in their village. It has been their main source of income for two years and, according to her, their business is doing better. Their income is being used to support the educational needs of their three children.

She is requesting a loan of PHP 4,000 for the development of their business. She will need the loan to purchase more materials needed for her manufacturing business, such as various kinds of wood. Nora dreams of expanding her business in order to generate more income to provide the needs of her family. Nora is 36 years old. She is married to Rolando, who is also a farmer. They own farmland and it is an additional source of income for their family. The couple has four children, three of whom are presently studying. They live in the village of Ballacong, Ilagan, Isabela.

loans.use: Development of her furniture manufacturing business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sophoin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophoin P., who is 39 years old, and her husband, Mr. Belasambath Norng, 34, have been married since 1998 and have three daughters. Two of them are garment factory workers and the other one attends school. They live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sophoin has been a silk weaver for 23 years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village where she lives, who then takes it to sell in the Phnom Penh market. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to buy a motorbike for commuting, and she will use part of her loan to buy silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for commuting and silk materials for weaving.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia C. is from the village of Inasagan, Aurora, Zamboanga del sur. She is 48 years old and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, Lilia owns and operates a business buying and selling dry cloth in the local community. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $112 a month from these activities.

In 2007, Lilia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional new items for sell. This will be her 5th loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional new items to sell

loans.name: Vong

texts.en: S. is an older mother living in Siem Reap Province. She has two children,\; one is married and one is single, and they both earn money to help meet the family's living expenses. Since 2000, S. has run a business selling fish. She sells fish that she either gets from her husband's fishing or buys from her supplier and she is currently earning an average of $2 each day. She also uses her own old vehicle for her business activities. Because fish selling is the main way for her to earn money, S. is applying a loan to purchase more nets and traps for her husband’s fishing activities.

loans.use: To purchase more nets and traps for her husband’s fishing activities

loans.name: Alberto

texts.en:
Albert is a 45-year-old business man. He lives in Ballacong, Ilagan, Isabela together with h is wife and children. Aside from being a farmer, Albert also has a sideline which involves retailing. Albert is married to Gemma, and has two school-aged children. He works hard for the needs of his family. He must be responsible to meet their daily needs and he want his children to finish their studies. He doesn’t want them to be like him who did not finish his studies. He hopes to provide them good future through complete education.

Albert is engaged in retailing big animals such as cows and carabao (water buffaloes). He purchases animals directly from Pangasinan and sells them in various villages of Isabela. Each animal costs a lot and he needs more capital to increase the stock that he buys. He is requesting a loan for his buy-and-sell business. He hopes that KIVA lenders can help him expand his business so that he can support the studies of his two children.

loans.use: Buy and sell cows and carabaos (water buffaloes)

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie M. lives in the village of Nabantu-an 1, Brgy Balintawak, Escalante City Negros Occidental. She is 48 years old, and married to Roberto M. who works as a laborer in the Ceres bus terminal. They have 3 children who are between 5 and 19 years old. Tessie has accepted the reality that her husband’s income is just too small to sustain their family's growing needs. This is why she explored ways to help her husband by earning on her own, because she also dreamed that her children would be able to finish their college education, have gainful work and live a more comfortable life.

It was quite providential that a friend invited her to join NWTF-Project Dungganon, and with her husband's consent, she became a member in 1997 and she used her loans to start a general store. The business turned out to be a good investment for it had an immediate impact by lightening the burden of the household expenses from her husband's shoulders. When a new opportunity arose to buy and sell scrap materials (old metals, plastic, bottles, etc.), she jumped at the chance and it improved her business income even further. Now her business earns an average net income of PHP 2,400 per month.

In her previous loan, she borrowed the amount of PHP 12,000, which she used as additional working capital for her general store and scrap business. The loan was fully paid on time, maintaining her standing as a good member. Now she is borrowing for her 12th cycle loan the same amount of PHP 12,000 to be used as additional capital for her businesses. She plans to use the income from this venture for house repairs and as a start-up capital for a new business which she is presently exploring.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her businesses

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raquel P. produces snacks which she sells within their village. According to her, she needs additional capital amounting to PHP 5,000 for the growth of her business. She hopes that she can avail herself of this loan so that she can immediately buy the ingredients needed in cooking of her snacks. She said that having sufficient capital to run her business can help her to make it more productive.

Raquel is married to Celso who works as a driver. Her husband is in full support of running their business. She hopes that they can make it more productive. They have been blessed with two children: Russel Dave, nine years old, an elementary pupil and Celestine Tyra, seven years old.

loans.use: Buy ingredients for her snack vending

loans.name: Libertino

texts.en:
"Time is Gold,” is the guiding principle of Libertino for he wanted to use his time wisely to become productive. He needs to work hard and be patient to be able to provide for the needs of his family. Libertino is single and living with his mother and sister.

Libertino runs a sari-sari store (community-based store) in their village. He usually purchases his commodities in Tuguegarao City once a month. According to him, he has been in business for nine years and he tries to maintain it for the sake of his family. Libertino is requesting a loan of PHP 7,000 for the maintenance and continuous development of his business. He hopes that the lenders will approve his loan request.

loans.use: Additional capital for his village store

loans.name: Rosalita

texts.en:
Rosalita D.'s main source of income comes from buying scrap metal for sale. She is 56 years old, widowed and has seven grown-up children. She is from the village of D'ban, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Rosalita has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2008, Rosalita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Rosalita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC which was used to purchase materials needed to expand her services. Rosalita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional scrap metal to sell. This will be her second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement her family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase scrap metal to sell

loans.name: Rowna Farahnaz Group

texts.en:
This is Rowna Farahnaz group, made up of three members. Ahmad Jawad is the group leader.

Ahmad Jawad is about 55 years old and is married with five children. He has a general store and all the family members benefit from its income. He wants to expand his business and to attract more clients.

The second member is Rowna. She is a tailor and works hard to earn money for the completion of her family’s requirements. She needs to buy a new sewing machine for her business because she has lots of problems with old one while sewing. Besides that, she wants to hire a student to support him in her business and to enlarge her business.

The last group member is Farahnaz and she wants to take a loan for her brother’s bakery shop. With the loan, her brother wants to expand his business and buy required materials.

They have together requested a group loan of 30,000 Afghani to change the status of their businesses and their lives. They admire this effective process.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora E. is from the village of Southwestern Pob., Calamba, Misamis Occidental.She is 28 years old, she is married and has three school-age children. Nora owns and operates a business venture in retail sector operating a specialized retail store.While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling electronic products in the local community. Nora has been in her business for one and half year and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Nora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Nora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC.This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. Nora is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Nora from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Malika Talash Group

texts.en:
This is Malika Talash group which has four members: Naik Bakat, Leela, Malika and Gul J., all of whom live in district 13 of Kabul, Afghanistan. Naik Bakat is the group leader.

Naik Bakat is 30 years old and lives in a family of six members. She has been a tailor since the Taliban regime and has sewed clothes because at that time they had lots of economic problems. Now, with the Kiva loan, she wants to buy a new sewing machine and wants to start her business in a new direction to support her family members.

Leela is the second member. She wants to take a loan for her husband who has fuel-selling shop. Through its income he supports his family members and his purpose of obtaining the loan is to expand his business

The third member is Mahlika who has a carpet-weaving business. She wants to buy better materials for carpet weaving and wants to support all her family members.

The last member is Gul J. who has quilt-making business. She wants to buy all the necessary materials which she needs for her business.

So they together have requested a group loan of 42,000 Afghani. They would like to say thanks to Kiva lenders who are able to support all entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Khuy

texts.en:
Khuy S., 53, is a rice farmer who has been farming since 2004. Currently, he owns a machine which he uses to provide plowing or transporting services for a fee. He is married with two single children who both work as teachers. His wife sells a few fish in the market to earn a living and is also a good homemaker who cooks tasty meals for the family.

Khuy S. is running his business smoothly but unfortunately his farming machine is often broken which affects his income. Because of this problem, Khuy S. is applying for a loan to repair his machine.

Note: Khuy S. was busy at work, so his wife is in the photo instead.

loans.use: To repair his farming machine

loans.name: Sokhay

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhay K. is 37 years old and the mother of three children. One of her children is a construction worker, and another attends the local school. The youngest is too young to work or study.

Sokhay lives in Prey Run Village in the Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. This is how she earns a living. In addition to her plantation, Sokhay is a pig breeder.

She is now applying for a loan so she can buy more piglets, pig food and fertilizers. She would also like to hire laborers to work in the rice field.

She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's livelihood with this loan.

Her husband, Mr. Yun Sam Oeun, is a construction worker. He is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more piglets, pig food and fertilizer; to hire laborers to work in the rice field.

loans.name: Vuthy

texts.en:
Mr. Vuthy K. is 37 years old and the father of two children. His oldest child is enrolled in the local school, the youngest one is too young to work or study. His wife, Mrs. Chim Phary, is employed in a garment factory. He is a villager in Preak Sam Raung Village in the Kandal Province.

Vuthy K. owns a plot of land on which he cultivates rice. In addition to farming, he also sells soil. Unfortunately he does not earn enough income from his plantation to support his family's livelihood. Therefore, he decided to ask for a loan. He plans to use the loan to buy more land and cultivate more rice to earn additional income.

loans.use: To buy more land for rice cultivation

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Thouk

texts.en:
Thouk I. is an older woman and a widowed mother of four children. Her husband died of senility years ago.  

Two of her children are married and live independently, while other two are single. Thouk I. has been working as a rice farmer since her children were very young. Currently, she owns a piece of land, on which she cultivates different crops to earn a living. To help meet the family’s financial needs, one of her daughters is working for a hotel. Thouk I. saw that her daughter was having difficulty commuting to work because she doesn’t own a vehicle. So Thouk I. decided to seek a loan to purchase a used motorcycle for her daughter to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorcycle for her daughter to ride to work

loans.name: Leoniza

texts.en:
Leoniza B. is from the village of Labo, Ozamiz City. She is 44 years old. Leoniza is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Leoniza owns and operates food business. Leoniza has been engaged in her business for more than 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Leoniza joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials for her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for business

loans.name: Kimseng

texts.en:
Mrs. Kimseng Y. is 28 years old. She lives in Prey Run Village in the Takeo Province. To earn a living, she works as a Khmer cake seller. In addition to this business, she is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Bun Sao Ly, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultivates rice. He is also a construction worker. This couple has two children who are too young to work or study.

Mrs. Kimseng Y. is now requesting a loan to buy piglets, pig food, a cow, and fertilizers to support the rice field. She hopes to increase her family's income and improve the business.

Mr. Bun Sao Ly, her husband, is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy piglets, pig food, a cow, and fertilizers to support the rice field.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy and her husband Ben are farmers. They live in the village of Murong, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. They have three children, Vanessa, Lea and Krizel, who are all students.  Nancy and Ben work hard to earn their income and finance their children's educational needs.  They want their children to finish their studies so they will find stable jobs someday.

As farmers, Nancy and Ben want to increase their harvest to earn a higher income. In addition to the farm, Nancy manages a small sari-sari (community-based) store in their village to earn additional income. She wants to improve it but she has inadequate capital. Nancy is seeking to borrow PHP 9,000 from Kiva's lenders to purchase merchandise for her store. She hopes that with this financial assistance, she can improve her small business and support her children's education.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mr. Chantha P. is 29 years old. He lives in Preak Sam Raung Village in the Kandal Province. He is a grocer who owns a small grocery store. His wife, Mrs. Van Ny, is employed in a garment factory.

Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it by purchasing more grocery products to resell. This will allow him to earn more income to support his family's livelihood.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to resell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence, who is 43 years old, is married to Joseph M. Sr.  Her husband is a security guard. They are blessed with four children:  Mark Anthony, 20; Jennifer, 17; Joseph Jr.,16; and Jonalyn, who is four years old. They live in the village of Sta. Maria, Alicia, Isabela.

Florence has been working as a food vendor for almost three years. She sells rice cakes and cooked food in their village.  She earns a daily net income of PHP 200. That income is not sufficient for her family needs and the education of her children.  She is seeking a loan of PHP 5,000 from Kiva's lenders. She will use the loan to buy ingredients for her products. She hopes that lenders will approve her loan request to improve the productivity of her business.

loans.use: Additional capital for her food vending business

loans.name: Ratha

texts.en:
Mr. Ratha S. lives in Khsom Village in the Kandal Province. He is 30 years old and the father of three children. His oldest child attends the local school and the other two are too young to work or study. Ratha S. is a farmer; he owns a plot of land on which he cultivates rice and vegetables. His wife, Mrs. That Sophall, is a pig breeder. She uses the rice he grows to make rice wine, which she sells.

Now, Ratha S. would like to grow soy on his field. However, he does not have enough money to grow an additional crop. Therefore, he has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides to support a new soy field.

Mrs. That Sophall is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides to support a new soy field

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Almost everybody dreams of having a better future and uplifting their family's living conditions. One of those dreamers is Rosie R.. She says that she will do her best to meet the needs of her children. She and her husband are helping each other to be successful. Her husband is busy in the field while Rosie operates an eatery business – she sells food for lunches and snacks. Also, she has a small hog-raising business.

Rosie manages her business well because she knows that she can achieve her dreams with her profits. Her business is the key to fulfilling her dreams for her children. She wants her children to finish their education to alleviate their poverty. She believes that giving her children a good education is the best that she can do. Rosie wants to borrow 10,000 Philippine pesos for business capital.

loans.use: For business capital

loans.name: Saroem

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroem S. was born in 1962. She lives in Preak Ta Sao Village in the Kandal Province. She and her husband, Mr. Yort Vannak, are farmers who own a piece of land on which they grow vegetables. They have two children who are enrolled in the local school.

Now, they would like to grow an additional crop, beans, but they don't have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Saroem S. has decided to ask for loan. She will use the loan to buy bean seeds, beanpoles, fertilizers, pesticides, and to hire a laborer for plowing. She hopes to increase her family's income and improve their livelihood with this loan.

loans.use: To buy bean seeds, beanpoles, fertilizers, pesticides, and to hire a laborer for plowing.

loans.name: Loida

texts.en:
Loida B. is from the village of Bañadero in Ozamiz City. She is 44 years old and married, and has 5 school-aged children. She buys and sell RTW's. She has been engaged in this business for 5 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month.

In November 2007, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Loida has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. She is now requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP to use as additional capital for her ready-to-wear business. This will be her third loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family's financial needs.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional items for her ready to wear business

loans.name: Khen

texts.en:
Khen K. is 45 years old and married.  His wife is a local cultivator, and they have five children.  Two of his children are married and the others attend school. 

Khen K. currently generates an income of approximately $4 per day by selling marble. First, he purchases large marble blocks from people who live near the mountains, then he carves and breaks down the marble blocks into small pieces, and finally he sells the marble pieces to people who need them to carve statues. 

Typically, Khen K.  hires his neighbor’s water buffalo to transport the marble to be sold. To help reduce his costs, Khen K. is applying for a loan to purchase a pair of water buffalo which he will use to pick up and deliver the marble.

loans.use: To purchase a pair of water buffalo to pick up and deliver marble

loans.name: Lorelie

texts.en:
Lorelie A. is from the village of Catadman, Ozamiz City. She is 31 years old and married and she has no children. 

Lorelie owns an EXL Express package shipping franchise, a business that she personally manages. She has been engaged in this business for 3 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In August 2009, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorelie is now requesting her first loan of 25,000 PHP to use as capital for her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family.

loans.use: Additional capital for her EXL Express business

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda, 51 years old, is married to Rolando who works as a farmer. They have two children who are both married. Now that her children are done with their schooling and already have their own families, she believes that they will make it on their own. However, Yolanda is ready to assist her children in times of need.

Yolanda makes a living with her hog-raising business. She keeps them for four months. She has had her business since her children entered college. Through this business, she earns 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month which is a big help in meeting the daily needs of her family. She hopes that her business will further expand and become more productive, and that's why she is asking for financial assistance from Kiva lenders. She wants to borrow 20,000 PHP to buy hog feed and some hogs to raise.

loans.use: For hog feed and hogs to raise

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom H. lives in Ping Pong village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice. On this plantation she earns less income than needed to support her family. In order to reach their living requirements, she decided to ask for a loan to add her saving to buy a plot of land. She will use the land to cultivate rice to earn more income.

Mrs. Mom H. is 36 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Brok Sokhorn, is a blacksmith.

loans.use: To add to her savings to buy a plot of land to cultivate more rice

loans.name: Shiela Mae

texts.en:
Shiela Mae L. is from the village of Cotta in Ozamiz City. She is 24 years old and married and has 3 school-aged children. She manages a small grocery store. She has been in this business for 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In May 2009, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shiela has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. She is now requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP to use as capital for her grocery store. This will be her second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Mr. Koeng Yun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Koeng Y. is the president of the village bank loan consisting of 8 people located in Choes Village in Kandal province. All the members will use the loan for different purposes

Mr. Koeng Y. is 26 years old and the father of a child who is too young to work or study. His wife, Mrs. Sath Kosal, is employed in a garment factory.

Mr. Koeng Y. is a farmer who owns 1-hectar field of land to cultivate rice to earn his living. With this plantation he faces an obstacle because his field is infertile which has a bad effect on his crops.

In order to deal with this problem he decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers. He will use the rest of money to hire laborers to work on the field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and to hire laborers to work on the field.

loans.name: 06 Đông Sơn Group

texts.en:
"Nụ N. Thị lives in the town of Thanh Hoá and is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 06 Đông Sơn (06 Đông Sơn).


Nụ is 42 years old and married with 3 school-aged children.  To making a living, Nụ owns and operates a general store.  The main source of income for the business is selling a variety of different products in the local community.  Nụ has been engaged in this business for over 12 years and earns approximately 1500000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2006, Nụ joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Nụ has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3079800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Nụ from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Nụ plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  L. Thị Tuyết (90) is a 59 year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store operations.


2.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mr. Ngoeurn Suon Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Ngoeurn S. has been selected village bank president by the 13 members of the village bank loan. All the members live in Srel Duoch village in Takeo province and they all will use the loan for different purposes.

Mr. Ngoeurn S. is 43 years old and the father of two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other attends the local school.

He is a farmer who owns 2-hectar field of land to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. T. Sear, is a grocer who owns a grocery store. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it.

Thus, Mr. Ngoeurn S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery products to support his wife’s business.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to support his wife’s business.

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is married with two sons. She runs a pharmaceutical business in Ivano-Frankivsk next to a local children’s hospital. Olga owns 3 small pharmaceutical kiosks and sells medications to retail clients. She launched this business 6 years ago and she currently earns a net profit of 8,000 Grivnyas per month.     

Olga is seeking a loan of 8,200 Grivnyas to purchase assorted pharmaceuticals for the cold season when viruses, cold and flu lead to increased spending on medications. Olga’s business is the main source of income for the family and her husband is also actively involved in the business. One day Olga is hoping to continue to develop her business by opening several more pharmaceutical kiosks.

loans.use: to purchase assorted pharmaceuticals

loans.name: Annalen

texts.en:
"Patience is the key to success," says Annalen. She is 23 years old and married to Jerico R., a tricycle driver in their community. They are blessed with one child, four year old Lander. They are living in a harmonious Barangay of Baculud Iguig Cagayan.

Annalen sells rice and native cakes in their village and is able to earn Php5,000 a month. She dreams of improving her business so that she is able to earn a bigger income to meet the needs of her family. She would like to ask for financial support from KIVA lenders amounting to Php5,000. This amount will serve as a big help to make her businesses more productive.

loans.use: additional capital for her rice and native cake vending businesses

loans.name: Suon

texts.en:
Suon C. is a 32 year old mother of three children, all of whom are students. Suon runs a small market shop, selling various produce, such as fresh vegetable and meat. Suon has run her shop for more than a year and is earning an average of $5 per day.

Her husband is a construction foreman, which helps provide for their family. In order to increase her income, Suon C. has requested a loan of US$1000 to buy an old truck to use for providing a transportation service.

loans.use: To buy an old truck for providing a transportation service

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza B. is a 41 year old widow with two loving children, who study at the Day Care Center in their village. They are happily residing in the village of Pinoma, Cauayan City, two kilometers away from the national highway.

Analiza manages a business selling AVON cosmetics products and apparel, earning a net monthly income of Php 1,500.00. Aside from that she also sells some rice cakes and vegetables in their village.

Analiza would like to request a loan amount of Php 5,000.00, to purchase more AVON products. She would like to increase her income to meet her family's daily needs.

loans.use: to buy more AVON products to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Savann Soy Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Savann S. has been selected village bank president by the 9 members of the village bank loan. They all live in Srae Ampil village in Kandal province.

Mrs. Savann S. is 39 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are farmers and the other attends the local school.

She is a seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Pek Yoeun, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. He has a problem with his plantation because his field is infertile soil.

Thus, Mrs. Savann S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support the rice field to make the crops more productive.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to support the rice field to make the crops more productive.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is married entrepreneur from Skvira, where she sells women’s clothing, office supplies and groceries in the local markets. Valentina owns 3 vending locations at 3 different markets in the region. She has been in this business for 10 years. She currently has about 100,000 Grivnyas invested in her business; her average income is 28,000 Grivnyas a month, and her monthly net profit doesn’t exceed 8,000 Grivnyas.  

Valentina is seeking a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas to increase her working capital. We believe her natural ability to please her customers, by guessing their needs and offering speedy courteous service, will help Valentina achieve her goals, sustain her success and consequently win at the entrepreneurial game.

loans.use: to increase working capital

loans.name: Arceli

texts.en:
Arceli is 45 and is married to Bonifacio, who manages their farm in the village of Ballacong, Ilagan, Isabela where they live. They have two children - the older is a Criminology graduate and  the younger is a graduate in automotive training. Arceli still dreams that their two children will have a successful life someday. 

Arceli raises hogs.  Recently, she sold six hogs but still has others. Arceli wants a loan of PHP8,000 to buy feed for her pigs. According to her, she wants to expand her business for the welfare of her family.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her hogs

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: ce monsieur est un résident du quartier de DJIFA KPOTA, il est marié et père de deux (02) enfants. l'activité qu'il exerce pour subvenir aux charges de sa famille est la vente de viande de moutons et de boeufs à l'abattoir du grand marché de Lomé . il a démarré ce commerce depuis 1997. en ces périodes la demande est très élevée, ceci est dû à la période des fêtes de fin d'année. pour bien répondre à cette demande et accroître ses recettes, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 10 moutons et 05 boeufs.
texts.en:
This is a gentleman who lives in the Djifa Kpota neighborhood. He's married and the father of two children. The business he runs to support his family is consists in selling mutton and beef at the abattoir of the grand market in Lomé. He started this business in 1997. Demand is currently very high, due to the year-end holiday period. To meet this demand efficiently and increase his revenues, he's seeking a loan from Kiva's partner, WAGES, in order to buy 10 sheep and 5 oxen.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 10 sheep and 5 oxen

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
Felisa D. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 53, married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Felisa owns & operates a business planting and harvesting flowers for sale. Felisa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Felisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felisa repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI, which she used to purchase fertilizer. Felisa is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Svitlana

texts.en:
Svitlana is married and has one son. She is an entrepreneur from the town of Skvira, where she sells groceries -she owns two vending locations at two different markets. Svitlana has been in this business for 5 years. She has one hired employee who works at one of her vending kiosks. Currently, she has 65,000 Grivnyas invested in merchandise. Her average net profit amounts to 5,800 Grivnyas a month. 

Svitlana is seeking a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas to purchase additional merchandise and stock one of her grocery kiosks with confectionery inventory for the upcoming holiday season. Svitlana is very enthusiastic about her venture and business. She invests all her energy in her business and seeks its growth.

loans.use: to stock one of her kiosks with additional merchandise

loans.name: Heab

texts.en: Heab N. is a farmer who lives in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is 30 and is married to Mr. Soaly, 28, who works with her in the farming business. They work hard at their business activities every day and never waste time. To help with the farm work, Heab N. wants a loan to purchase a cow, which she will use for plowing the farmland. Heab N. is a good mother, blessed with two kids who are in school.

loans.use: To purchase a cow which she will use for plowing the farmland

loans.name: Mrs. Mach Chea Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Mach C. is a group leader of six members who all live in Ta Koam village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Mach C. is 26 years old and the mother of a child who is just 2 years old. Her husband, Mr. Chan Chorn, is a construction worker.

Mrs. Mach C. is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. She is also a pig breeder.

Since her pig breeding business is going well, Mrs. Mach C. wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets for breeding to earn more income.

loans.use: To buy more piglets to breed to earn more income.

loans.name: Jinky

texts.en:
Jinky is 29 years old and she is now a widow. She has five children. Jayson, 13 years old, is a second-year high school student. Jerry, 11 years old, is a grade four student. Jackson, 9 years old, is a grade three student. And their youngest, Kyla, seven years of age, is a grade one student. They reside in the village of Sta. Maria, Alicia, Isabela, a rural and plain area.
She has been engaged in the general store business for almost two years now. Her daily net income is PHP 200.00, and she's been working patiently to gain a productive income. She desires a loan of PHP 5,000.00 for additional capital for her store. She hopes that KIVA lenders will provide her the loan as soon as possible to be able to maintain the success of her business.

loans.use: Additional capital for her retail store

loans.name: Mrs. Rai Korb Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Rai K. has been selected village bank president by the 11 members of Village Bank Loan. All the members live in Krang Ta C. village in Takeo province and they all will use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Rai K. is 33 years old and the mother of four children who attend the local school. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. S. Sarath, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice.

Aside from this plantation, he is a construction worker. In this work, he has a problem because his work place is far from their house.

Thus, Mrs. Rai K. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.use: To add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.name: Kul

texts.en: Kul N. is a young woman and mother. She makes a living raising pigs, which she sells for slaughter after four months. She has been raising pigs for about four years and is currently earning around $3 a day. Kul N. is married with four school-aged kids. Her husband is Sophea, age 33. He is a local motor taxi driver who picks up passengers for a profit. Kul N. doesn't have a bathroom for her and her family, so she would like to request a loan to pay for the cost of building a bathroom.

loans.use: To pay the cost of building a restroom

loans.name: Rodalyn

texts.en:
Rodalyn has been engaged in direct selling for almost nine years now. Her net profit per month is PHP 500-750. She decided to request from KIVA lenders a loan of PHP 7,000.00 for additional capital to improve her business. She plans also to use it for repair and maintenance of their motorcycle.
Her husband is a tricycle driver and operator. Their marriage is blessed with five children. Their eldest is already married; the next is a tricycle driver;  then comes a third year high school student, a preschooler, and a two-year-old girl. She wants to improve and expand her business to earn more income so that she can pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: Additional capital to improve her business

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta H. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis, Oriental. She is 32 years old. Julieta is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Julieta owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Julieta has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Julieta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Julieta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha P. is commonly called Edit in their village. She is married to Mr. Johny who is a farmer. The couple is blessed with four children: Gilbert, who is a rice-grain delivery boy, Jun-Jun, Mary Ann, and Patricia. They live in the village of Del Corpuz, Cabatuan, Isabela.


She has been managing a food vending business for almost a year. She is also a vegetable vendor in their village. Every afternoon she sells her commodities immediately, because the village people love to eat vegetables and they are affordable. Her net income for her businesses is PHP 400 daily. She wants to take a loan of PHP6,000, which she will use for her food and vegetable vending. She is optimistic that KIVA lenders will grant her request.

loans.use: Additional capital for her Food Vending business

loans.name: Mr. Phanny Rorn Group

texts.en:
Mr. Phanny R. is the group leader of three members who all live in Trapeang Ampil village in Takeo province.

Mr. Phanny R. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which he cultivates rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a construction worker. His wife, Mrs. Chi Srey Oun, raises pigs and chickens. Now she wants to expand her business because it is going well. Thus, Mr. Phanny R. decided to request a loan to buy some more piglets and chickens to raise. He hopes to increase their income and improve the family living with this loan.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and chickens for his wife's business

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida is 27 years old and is married to Danny who is a construction worker in the village of Nagassican Santiago City. The couple is blessed with two children: PJ Dan, seven years old, is an elementary school student; and Danica Jane is two years old.

Leonida is a vegetable vendor in their village.  She would like to improve her vending business by asking for financial assistance from the KIVA lenders.  She is now requesting to borrow a loan of PHP5,000 so that she can purchase more vegetables.  She believes that by having enough capital, her business will become profitable.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables

loans.name: Nou

texts.en: P. is an old woman and a widowed mother. She is a local rice farmer who has been working in this sector since her children were very young. P., 47, has given birth to eight children. One of her sons is employed as a vehicle repairer. P. is taking out her loan to purchase more spare vehicle parts for her son’s business.

loans.use: To purchase more spare vehicle parts

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase chicks to raise and sell

loans.name: Mariama Malang

texts.fr: Mariama Malang M. a 45 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 8 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KANDE BANETO depuis 7 ans et demi, elle a une bonne expérience avec le crédit. Son activité consiste à acheter des régimes de bananes et les revendre au détail en faisant du porte à porte. Elle participe aux charges familiales à partir des bénéfices qui résultent de cette activité.
texts.en:
Mariama Malang M., age 45, is married and the mother of 8 children. She's been a member of the village bank of Kande Baneto for seven and a half years, and her past loan experiences went well. Her business consists in buying bunches of bananas and in retailing them door to door. With her profits, she contributes to the household expenses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her business (selling bananas)

loans.name: Mrs. Ron Nget Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of ten people, is located in Trapeang Khchau village in Takeo province and each member will use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Ron N. is the village bank president.

Mrs. Ron N. is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates both rice and vegetables. Now she wants to grow vegetables on the field but she does not have enough money. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to grow beans and soy on the field.

Mrs. Ron N. is 33 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Ou Chheang, is a soldier and he uses the rest of his time as a construction worker.

loans.use: To grow beans and soy on her field

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
At the age of 60, she is managing a mini-eatery in their village. At present, she is applying for a loan of PHP 7,000 to purchase some kitchen utensils and food ingredients to be used in her food retail business. Her daily net income is PHP 200. Luzviminda hopes that through her business, she can send her daughter to college by next year.

She is married to a farmer named Asencio. They have only one daughter and their family is peacefully residing in the village of Calaocan, Cabatuan, Isabela. Their house is near the Rice Mill in their village. She hopes that her requested loan will materialize immediately with the help of some kindhearted KIVA lenders, and that she will obtain her desired profits.

loans.use: To buy kitchen utensils and ingredients

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas N., 62 years old, is a snack food seller. She operates her business in front of her home. Besides selling food, she and her husband always cultivate a rice crop when the farming season approaches. Meas N. is a good mother blessed with eight kids. Six of the children are married and the other two are still young. Meas N. is applying for a loan to buy more essential ingredients to continue cooking food for sale.

loans.use: To buy more essential ingredients to continue cooking food for sale

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva V. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis, Oriental. She is 43 years old. Eva is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Eva owns & operates a business providing photography services to local community members. Eva has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Eva joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eva is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Eva from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her photography business

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Sim S., 49, is married with two children. They live in Kandal Province, Cambodia. To make a living, she sells various kinds of groceries at home, earning approximately US $7 per day. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. Her husband is a middle man who buy cows from the local farmers from the village and sells them to markets in the town;  he earns an income of US $5 per day. Mrs. S. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase more groceries to stock her store.

loans.use: buy groceries

loans.name: Mrs. Sinat On Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of fourteen people and they all live in Angk Ta Ngel village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sinat O. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. Sinat O. is a farmer who owns a piece of land O. which she cultivates rice. She also raises pigs. Since her pig business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets, pig food, and fertilizers to support her rice field.

Mrs. Sinat O. is 23 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Horn Tith, is a driver.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig food plus fertilizers to support her rice field

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie E. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 29, married and has 5 children. To make a living, Tessie owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Tessie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Tessie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI, which she used to to purchase additional products to sell. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which she will use to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita F. is from the village of Santo Niño. She is 61 years old. Juanita is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Juanita owns and  operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. She has been in business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Juanita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. Juanita is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be Juanita's 7th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell

loans.name: Mean

texts.en: Mean P., 27, is married with four children. She resides in Kandal Province, Cambodia with her husband (pictured) and children.
