To make a living, she  raises pigs for sale, earning approximately US $5 per day. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. Her husband is a middle man who buys bananas from the local farmers from the village and sells them to markets in the town, earning an income of US $5 per day. Mrs. P. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, P. is asking for a loan of US $400 to purchase bananas and pig food to expand their current businesses.

loans.use: buy bananas and pig food

loans.name: Vong

texts.en:
Vong V. is a 37-year-old father of five teenage children, all of whom are in school. His wife raises poultry and grows rice. Since early 2005, he has made a living both driving a taxi and working in construction. He normally earns around $4 of income per day to support his family and buy them food. Vong V. will use his loan to construct a toilet for his family's hygiene. 

Note: Vong V.'s wife appears in the photograph

loans.use: To construct a toilet for his family's hygiene

loans.name: Mrs. Rim Meak Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twelve people who are all living in Rim M. village in Takeo province make up this village bank loan. They will each use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Rim M. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. Rim M. and her husband, Mr. U. Voeun, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice to earn a living. Now, Mrs. Rim M. is applying for a loan to buy a cow for breeding and to use to plow the rice field.

Mrs. Rim M. is 44 years old and the mother of six children, one of whom is a construction worker, another is a laborer, three are attending the local school, and the remaining one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding and for plowing her rice field

loans.name: Cresencia

texts.en:
Cresencia would like to borrow Php 8,000 from KIVA lenders to pursue her livestock business. She plans to purchase native chickens to raise as an additional source of income. She hopes to further expand her business and purchase more poultry feed for her native chickens. With this loan, she also hopes to start a hog-raising business.

Cresencia is 55 years old and is married to Andy M., a company truck driver. They are blessed with three children, one of whom is married. They live happily in Calaocan, Cabatuan, Isabela with their grandson. Cresencia hopes that, with her loan, she can improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy chickens and chicken feed and start a hog-raising business

loans.name: Macarlina

texts.en:
Macarlina G. is from the village of Tagoloan in Misamis Oriental. She is 41 years old. Macarlina is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Macarlina sells seafood, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Macarlina has been in business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Macarlina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Macarlina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. She use her previous loan to purchase new items to sell. Macarlina is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Macarlina's second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en:
Natividad, 32 years old, is from the village of Larion Alto Tuguegarao City where farming is the major source of income of the residents. The couple is blessed with two children and both of them are studying. Her husband Ronald is 39 years old and works as a security guard.

Natividad has been raising pigs for eight years. She engaged in this business with a desire to assist her husband provide the daily needs of their family and send their children to school. They hope that the children will finish their college education. For this reason, Natividad and her husband are working hard for their future welfare. Sometimes her children also help her maintain her hogs, especially during weekends. 

She believes that with their cooperation and patience, a lot of improvement will happen to their business. In this regard, Natividad wanted to ask for additional business capital from the KIVA lenders amounting to PHP10,000. She intends to use the loan to buy a sufficient supply of feed so her hogs will be healthy and free from sickness.

loans.use: To buy feed for her hogs

loans.name: James' Group

texts.en: R. James is the leader of his lending group in Ntungamo. He is a hard working man, married with four children aged 12, 10, 7 & 4 years, all in primary school. James has been selling agricultural produce in Rwabashenyi Cell for 10 years and he is able to make 65,000/= profit a week. He sells mostly matooke and he is doing well because he has better yields now that he takes loans to improve them. He hopes to be able to make more profits from the same yields as well as being able to educate his children to the University level. James needs a loan to be able to improve his banana plantation by acquiring more manure and fertilizers for better output.

loans.use: To buy manure and fertilizer

loans.name: Men

texts.en: Men C., 51, is married with four children. She resides in Kandal Province, Cambodia with her husband and children. To make a living, she and her husband grow a few types of vegetable to meet the market’s demand, earning an income of approximately US $5 per day. This primary source of income helps cover the household expenses. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. Mrs. C. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, C. is asking for a loan of US $1200 to purchase more vegetables from the local villagers in her province for resale.

loans.use: To buy vegetables for resale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace M. is a 39-year-old widow. She has 5 children and 2 other dependents between the ages of 11 and 25 years. Grace lives in the Gasabo District where she has had a variety shop for the past 10 years. Her business is open from 6 AM to 9 PM every day and she employs one person.

Grace is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. She wants to update her shop by installing electricity and buying a refrigerator. With these upgrades, Grace will be able to sell cold drinks, which are preferred by many of her customers. If she is successful, she can continue to pay her children's school fees, renovate her house, and build a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To install electricity and buy a refrigerator for her store

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
Fely N. is from the village of Camp Phillips Bukidnon. She is 48 years old. Fely is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Fely owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Fely has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Fely joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fely has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Fely is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Fely from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan S., 28, is married. She resides in Kandal Province, Cambodia with her husband. To make a living, she and her husband grow specific types of vegetables such as beans and salads to serve the market’s demand, earning collectively an income of US $10 per day. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. This primary source of income helps cover the household expenses. Mrs. S. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase construction materials to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy construction materials to repair the house

loans.name: Rosevilla

texts.en:
Rosevilla is from the village of Taguilon. She is 36 years old. Rosevilla is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosevilla raises and sells pigs. Rosevilla is just starting this business.

In 2007, Rosevilla joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosevilla has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Rosevilla is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be Rosevilla's second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to educate her children. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Rubimbiri Group Of Ntungamo

texts.en:
Alice K. is the leader of her lending group in Ntungamo. She is 50 years old and married with 6 children, ages 8 – 23 years old. She also cares for 2 dependents. Her children attend primary and secondary schools. 

Alice is a hard-working lady who has been selling agricultural produce in Rubimbiri for about 9 years. She make 30,000/= (Ugandan shillings) in profits each week. She is grateful for her loans because they allow her to sell quality produce in her stall. In the future, she would like to expand so she can earn more income. She hopes to provide sustainability, prosperity and education for her family. 

Alice needs a loan to buy manure and fertilizer for her banana plantation to improve her yield.

loans.use: To buy manure and fertilizers for her bananas

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea T., age 29, lives in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She earns a living by selling groceries from her house, including cooked foods, soft drinks, plastic goods, and sweets for children. She has been in this business for a long time and has much experience. 

Chea T. is married and cares for four children, all of whom are single and attend school. Her husband is a local motorcycle taxi driver. Chea T. works hard every day and is a very responsible for her family. Recently, she sold all her groceries from her store, because of grocery selling is Chea T.'s main way to earn an income to support her family. She would like to ask for a loan to purchase a range of groceries to sell. With the remaining amount, she will build a grocery store. 

Chea T. and her husband appear in the photograph.

loans.use: To purchase groceries to sell and to build a grocery store

loans.name: Rem

texts.en:
Rem S., age 32, is married and has three school-aged children. She resides in Kandal Province, Cambodia with her husband and children. To make a living, she is employed seasonally to harvest vegetables for other farmers, earning an income of approximately US $4 per day. 

This is her first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva field partner. Her husband is a dedicated farmer who grows different types of beans and salad vegetables, earning an income of US $5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Mrs. S. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $800 to purchase a plot of farmland to expand her agriculture business.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en:
Clementine M., age 35, is married and has 5 children between the ages of 3 to 13 years. She also cares for another dependent. Clementine has been selling soft drinks and milk since 2005. She employs 2 people in her business. She is a proven and hardworking entrepreneur who works from 8 AM to 10 PM every day.

Clementine is now requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. She wants to buy a refrigerator, so she can sell cold drinks. This will allow her to expand her business and increase her sales significantly. She also hopes to attract many new customers. If her plan is successful, with the profits from her loan, Clementine will continue to pay school fees for her children and build a secure future for her young family.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Judy

texts.en:
Judy Y. is from the village of Baikingon , Cagayan de Oro City. She is 35 years old. Judy is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Judy owns and operates a small neighborhood retail store. While it is not her only means for generating revenue, the main source of income from her business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Judy has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP (just over $100 U.S.) a month for these activities.

In 2008, Judy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and better her ability to engage in business activities. Judy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Judy is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Judy from HSPFI.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of Opportunity International's accredited partners in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Working capital to operate and expand a small general store.

location.town: Baikingon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Daylethan

texts.en: N. is 23 years old and lives with his parents and siblings in a house in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. Using his own truck, N. operates a coal trading business in his town. He makes approximately six trips per month to the capital of the province to buy coal and bring it back to his town for resale with each round trip totaling 300 kilometers. He began his business in 2007, and since then, he has made enough money to buy his own house. He says, “I am planning on getting married next year and because of that, I would like to expand my business in order to save up money so that I can start a family.” N. is requesting a 600,000 tugrug (~$420 U.S.) loan in order to purchase a large amount of coal for his business. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team. To see if there are other Mongolian borrowers in need of funding, please click here

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of coal for resale.

loans.name: Ourt

texts.en:
Ourt E. makes a living by buying vegetables from local farmers for stock, earning approximately $6 US per day. He is 33 years old and married with three school-age children. His wife works full-time growing crops, earning $5 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. He resides in Kandal Province, Cambodia with his wife (pictured) and children. 
Mr. E. and his family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, E. is asking for a loan of $800 US to purchase more vegetables to sell to the markets. This is his first loan from Kiva’s partner, CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Candelaria

Candelaria owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling specialty food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Candelaria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Candelaria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

texts.en: Felicia R. is from the village of Ospital, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 56 years old, is widowed, and has four adult children. Felicia is just starting a business venture in the retail sector running a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She plans to use the revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. In 2008, Felicia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used for house renovation. Felicia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to complete the house renovation. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. loans.name: Chhem

texts.en:
Chhem C. makes a living selling various groceries at home in her village, earning approximately $4 US per day. She is 44 years old and married with two school-age children. Her husband works full-time growing rice and purchasing rice from local farmers to resell. These businesses are able to generate an income of $3 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. C. lives in Kandal Province, Cambodia with her husband (pictured) and children.

Mrs. C. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, C. is asking for a loan of $1100 US to purchase rice and more groceries to stock the store. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy groceries and rice to sell

loans.name: Kemishego Development, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
T. Florence has been a farmer since 1990. She is a hardworking and devoted lady. She is 40 years old and married with three children, ages 18, 14 and 13 years old, and she takes care of two dependants. Although she has challenges, like limited capital, she is able to make 300,000/= in profit a month and this helps her take care of her family and contribute to the family's development.

Florence is the leader of her group. She mostly sells agricultural produce and she has been able to win many customers due to her good customer care. She longs to have an expanded business as well as to provide the best education for all her children. Florence needs a loan to help improve her banana plantation by getting more fertilizers and purchasing manure.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and manure

loans.name: Chuluunmunkh

texts.en:
E. is 57 years old and lives with his wife and two adult daughters in a house in the Uvurkhangai province of Mongolia. E.’s wife sells coal and firewood at a local market while he operates a motorcycle taxi service in his town. He started his business in 1999 and since then has been transporting people all over the province with his motorcycle. He would like to expand his business in the future as well as build a house for his eldest daughter where she and her family can live comfortably. He says, “My only wish is for my children to be good people who use their intelligence to make this country better.” E. is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~350 USD) loan in order to purchase motorcycle parts and furniture for his home.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle parts and furniture for his home

loans.name: C2584 Twitezimbere Group

texts.en:
Laurent K. is 34 years old and is married with four children aged between 5 and 12 years. He lives in the Gasabo district near Kigali, the capital of Rwanda. He is the president of a group called Twitezimbere. This group has sold agricultural foodstuffs (sorghum, beans, etc.) for the past four years and it employs five people working from 5 a.m. to 10 p.m. every day. 

This group is now requesting its first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding their business. They will use the loan to purchase additional and larger quantities of foodstuffs needed by a number of their customers.

With this loan, and assuming they are successful, they hope to get enough profit to allow them to buy their own warehouse and provide more food and a better standard of living for their families.

loans.use: To purchase additional and larger quantities of foodstuffs

loans.name: Chhom

texts.en: Chhom S. is 42 and lives in Kandal Province, Cambodia with her husband and child. To make a living, she and her husband grow a few types of vegetables (beans, rice, and cucumbers), earning approximately US $2.50 per day to help cover the family expenses. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. Mrs. S. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $300 to purchase vegetable seed to expand her farming products.

loans.name: Tsembel

texts.en:
Tsembel M. is 53 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in a small house in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. Both of her daughters, Huyagmaa and Mungunhuyag, are university students. M. operates a small grocery business, where she sells a variety of food products at the local market. M. started her business in 2000, and has built a stable operation over the years. Her earnings have created financial stability for her family and have enabled her to buy land and build a new house. M. is a very hardworking businesswoman and is known for her good character. She says, "My one goal is to increase my earnings so that I can provide a good education for my children." She is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan (~2800 USD) to purchase grocery products to sell at her business.

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en:
Mr. Chhum U., 55 and his wife, Mrs. Saroem Eam, 40, live in a small village along National Road Number Five, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1989 and have one son and one daughter. 

Chhum has had full-time employment in Phnom Penh for 20 years, while his wife has been selling porridge in front of garment factory for 5 years. He is requesting his first loan of US $700 to buy a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa C. is from the city of Oroquieta. She is 32 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Elsa owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale.

In October 2009, Elsa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase a piglet

loans.name: Vianey

texts.en:
Vianey N. is 27 years old and is married with two children aged 5 years and 6 months. He lives in Gasabo district which is forty-five minutes drive from Kigali.

Vianey has worked as a butcher for a long time - this is his successful tenth year in this business! He employs three people  who help in various ways to make the shop run more efficiently. The hours of his business require that he works from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day.

Vianey is now requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to buy a fridge, which will help him to properly store the meats that he sells. Also, with more storage space, he will be able to increase the quantity of meats that he sells.

If his strategy is successful, Vianey hopes to earn more profits which will allow him to take care of his children through providing more food, paying school fees and generally building a more secure future for them.

loans.use: To buy a fridge

loans.name: Vong

texts.en: Vong A., 50, lives in Kandal Province, Cambodia with her husband and seven children. To make a living, she produces rice wine and raises pigs for sale, earning approximately US $3 per day. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. Her husband helps A. with these businesses and is able to earn the same amount of income. Mrs. A. and her family members are seeking to improve their standA. of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, A. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase pig food. By doing so, their pigs will grow efficiently and be able to reach the maximum size required by the market’s demand.

loans.use: buy pig food

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mrs. Mary L., 49 and her husband, Mr. Mat Sos, 50, live along National Road Number Six, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1985 and have six children: four sons and two daughters. The daughters are married and live in separate homes, two sons are fishermen and two sons are in school. Her husband is a fisherman.

Mary sells fish that her husband catches at the village market. Some of her husband’s fishing nets are broken, so she is requesting a loan of $600 to help purchase new fishing nets, so he will able to continue his business.

loans.use: To purchase new fishing nets for her husband’s fishing business.

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean de Dieu H. is 25 years old and is married with one child of 8 months. He lives in the Kicukiro district where he has had a shop selling a variety of shoes since 2001. The hours of his business requires that he works from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Jean de Dieu, after realizing that his working capital is still inadequate to grow his business with new offerings, is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. He needs the loan in order to purchase a variety of more attractive shoes which he hopes will increase the number of his customers as well as his profits.

If this strategy is successful, Jean de Dieu will be able to continue to build a secure future for himself and his child.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of more attractive shoes and handbags

loans.name: Nyabugando Tukwananise, Ntungamo Group

texts.en: M. Sarafina is the leader of her lending group in Ntungamo. She is 45 years old and married with 12 children, 4 of whom are still in school.  She is a very hard working lady and for 20 years has had a business selling agricultural produce from Nyabugando Cell.  Sarafina buys most of the produce from other farmers in addition to those from her farm. She is able to make 94000 UGX as profits a week, which enables her to save as well as pay for educating and taking care of her family. Sarafina needs a loan to help buy more seeds to plant since now is the rainy season, which is good for planting.

loans.use: Buying seeds to plant since this is a rainy season.

loans.name: Marifel

texts.en: Marifel A. is from the village of Libertad Alto, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old, is married, and has seven school-aged children. Marifel owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-one years and earns approximately 2,400 PHP a month. In 2005, Marifel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to pay for services to increase crop yield. Marifel is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be her 10th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Phom

texts.en: S. is  25, married and the mother of one lovely young child. She owns a small rattan-selling business. She always collects to buy rattan cupboard in bulk from her nearby neighbors and then takes it to sell door-to-door in the community. Her husband assists with her in selling the produce. S. faces difficulty with transporting her items to sell, because she doesn’t have her own vehicle. Therefore, S. has decided to ask a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL in order to purchase a trailer and a motorcycle, which she will use as transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer which she will use as transportation

loans.name: Narin

texts.en:
Mr. Narin K., age 31 and his wife, Mrs. Vancy Maung, age 22, live along National Road Number six, about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2000 and have three children: one son and two daughters;  two of them are in school and other is still too young.   

Narin has been driving a motor taxi for 5 years. His wife works in a NGO as a volunteer. Their house needs to be repaired,  so he is asking for his first loan of $700 in order to make the repairs.

loans.use: To repair his house.

loans.name: Jovita

texts.en:
Jovita M. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 51 years old. Jovita is married and has two grown children. To make a living, Jovita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Jovita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Jovita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. She wished to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Jovita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. Jovita is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Jovita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en: Milagros D. is from the village of Dohinob. She is 64 years old and is married. Milagros owns and operates a business providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Milagros joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. Milagros is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and be able to save for the future. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Méta Niassé

texts.fr: Méta Niassé MANE est une femme de 44 ans; elle est mariée et mère de 6 enfants dont elle a la charge. Depuis 7 ans et demi elle milite dans le Banc Villageois de KANDE BANETO et y a fait des performances remarquables. Elle est vendeuse d'huile de palme et de cacahouètes, son crédit lui permettra de renforcer ses activités afin de se procurer des bénéfices afin de pouvoir participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Méta Niassé Mané, aged 44, is married and the mother of six children whom she supports. She has been an active member of the village bank Kandé Banéto with remarkable achievements for seven and a half years. Méta Niassé is active in the sale of palm oil and peanuts. This loan will enable her to strengthen her business. She will use her profit to be able to improve the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen her business finances

loans.name: Zabir Group

texts.en:
This Zabir group has two members that include Jamela and Aziza. Jamela is the group leader. They would appreciate a loan to buy new sewing machines for their tailoring business, which they want to develop and expand. Jamela and Aziza need new machines because they have had lots of problems with the old ones.

They would like to be able to support all their family members with the income they generate. Jamela and Aziza have requested a group loan of 29000 Afghani. They say Kiva has the best process for securing a loan.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is divorced with one adult son. She sells children's clothing at a downtown market in the city of Zaporozhye. Tatyana has been in this business for 10 years, and in this time has been able to develop her business well. She has two business locations, a large assortment of inventory and many repeat clients. Her income is about 4,000 UAH per month.
 
Tatyana would like to borrow 11,300 UAH to purchase winter inventory. Tatyana loves her job and does it well. She hopes to develop her business further and increase her volume of customers even more.

loans.use: To purchase winter inventory

loans.name: 07.1.4 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en: Nguyệt N. Thị (18) is a 51 year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Nguyệt is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 07.1.4 Nam Ngạn (02.07.1.4). Nguyệt is widowed and has 1 adult child. Nguyệt owns & operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling rice products in the local community. Nguyệt has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1,200,000 VND a month from these activities. In 2007, Nguyệt joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nguyệt has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. The loan will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Nguyệt plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 1. T. Thị Hiếu (19) is a 61 year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business making & selling food. 2. Ngô Thị Nga (20) is a 45 year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business making & selling food. 3. Ngô Thị Lan (21) is a 38 year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 4. Lê Thị Nga (22) is a 54 year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business making & selling food. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** Nguyệt N. Thị (18) là 51 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh hoá. Nguyệt là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 07.1.4 Nam Ngạn (02.07.1.4). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ gạo trong cộng đồng địa phương. Nguyệt thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Nguyệt kiếm được khoảng 1.200.000 VND. Vào 2007, Nguyệt đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Nguyệt đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. T. Thị Hiếu (19) là 61 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 2. Ngô Thị Nga (20) là 45 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 3. Ngô Thị Lan (21) là 38 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 4. Lê Thị Nga (22) là 54 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en: Lilia C. is from the village of Libertad Alto, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old, is married, and has three adult children. Lilia owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over fourteen years and earns approximately 2,100 PHP a month. In 2005, Lilia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hang

texts.en:
Hang D. is 30 years old and a married man. Hang D. was married years ago and has no child yet. He is currently a recycling seller - he buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other countries. The used goods he deals in are mostly leftover electrical wires and plastic. Additionally, his wife stays at home to braid rattan furniture for sale.

Hang D. is looking for a loan to buy a new motorcycle in order to make his family transportation easier. Hang D. was not available at that day, so his wife is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle in order to make family transportation easier

loans.name: Sothea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sothea L., 34, has been married to Mr. Phat Veng since 1997. They have two children, one son and one daughter. Both of them are still young and attend school. They are living on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sothea is a silk weaver. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a wooden house builder. She hopes to supplement her other business raising cows.  She will get extra income from selling cows when they grow big enough. Hence, Sothea is asking for a loan of $1,200 to purchase cows to raise.

loans.use: To purchase cows to raise.

loans.name: Jean Pierre

texts.en:
Jean Pierre A. is 27 years old, is single, and lives in Gikongoro in Southern Province where he has a small kiosk selling various meats, including goat as a specialty. He employs three people in his business, which is open from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day.

Jean Pierre is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through purchasing meats and supplies that allow him to roast meats.

With this loan, Jean Pierre hopes to increase his number of customers and hopefully earn more profits in the process. This, in turn will allow him to build a secure future for himself and (hopefully, someday!) his family.

loans.use: To purchase meats and supplies for roasting

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Mr. Touch S. is 36 years old and a resident of Kompong Tom Province, where he earns a living raising ducks and pigs in a cage behind his house. He raises ducks for their eggs and sells the eggs to people who come to buy in bulk at his house. He is married with three children, one of whom is married and starting a family; the other two attend school. His wife stays at home and works with him in the business.

Touch S. has applied for an $800 loan from Kiva’s partner HKL in order to purchase additional feed and ducklings to raise.

loans.use: To purchase additional feed and ducklings to raise

loans.name: El

texts.en:
Mr. El M., 60 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Slamas M., age 63, live along National Road Number Six, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1978 and have ten children: three sons and seven daughters. Six of their children are married and live outside the family home, and other two are garment factory workers.

The couple are fisherfolk. In addition to fishing themselves, they buy fish from other fishermen and sell these on the other side of the Mekong River. Some of their fishing materials have worn down and no longer function properly, so Mr. El M. is asking for a loan of $1,200 to purchase new fishing materials to replace them.

loans.use: To purchase new fishing materials for his fishing business.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi A. is married and has one child. She has received a junior high education. Naomi sells soft drinks at Elmina near Ankwanda, which she has been doing since 2007. Her husband is a trader. Naomi uses her income to assist in the payment of their children's school fees and the family's utility bills.

Naomi intends to use the loan to purchase more soft drinks for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Naomi plans to save to build a house.

loans.use: Naomi intends to use the loan to purchase more soft drinks for sale.

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Mrs. Phalla S., 49, and her husband, Mr. Vin Reach, 48, were married in 1979. They have one son and two daughters. Their daughters weave silk at home and their son is attending school. The family lives on an Island on the Mekong River, about 12 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Phalla has been selling grocery items for over four years. She buys these at market in Phnom Penh for resale at her shop in front of her house. Her husband is a motor taxi driver.

Phalla is requesting a loan in the amount of $400 to continue expanding her business.

loans.use: To continue expanding her business.

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sabougnouma de l’association Benkadi sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 36 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Massigui, sous préfecture de MASSIGUI, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers et la restauration. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. Elles sont à leur douzième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter des habillements pour hommes et femmes et une grande quantité de céréales pour la restauration. Les habillements sont achetés en grande partie à Bamako et à Fana, quant aux céréales et aux condiments alimentaires pour la restauration, ils sont achetés en détail dans les villages environnants et sont revendus au marché de Massigui à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 39 000FCFA  par mois qui sera utilisé pour la nourriture,  la santé et  le réinvestissement dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Sabougnouma group of the Benkadi association are married women who average 36 years of age and 3 children. They live with their husbands and children in large traditional families in the Massigui village, in the Massigui sub-prefecture, Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali.

They got acquainted by links of neighborhood and kinship. They sell various items and do catering. Eager to always have financial support for their businesses, these women work with Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are seeking their twelfth solidarity loan (group loan). All previous loans were repaid without problem.

They intend to use this loan to buy men's and women's clothing, and a large quantity of cereals for their catering business. The clothes are purchased mostly in Bamako and Fana, whereas cereals and condiments are purchased in the surrounding villages. They sell at the Massigui market, to a clientele comprising both men and women.

They foresee turning a monthly profit of XOF 39'000 (ca US$ 90) each, to be in part used to provide food and healthcare to their families, and in part reinvested into their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing and cereals

loans.name: At

texts.en:
Mrs. At Chum and her husband, Mr. Bros Sun, were married in 1983 and have three sons and three daughters. They live in a small village along the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

At used to be a silk weaver, but she has now transferred her loom to her children. Her husband is a farmer. She is asking for a loan of $900 to purchase silk materials for her children’s weaving business and to help provide capital for her husband's farming business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her children’s weaving business and to help provide capital for her husband's farming business.

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Badenya sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 34 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Massigui, sous préfecture de MASSIGUI, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. 
Elles font le  commerce d’articles divers et la restauration, surtout les jours de foire. 
Dans le souci d’avoir un soutien financier en vue  de prendre en charges une partie des dépenses de leur famille, ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles sont à leur douzième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents se sont bien dénoués. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, elles vont acheter des habillements pour hommes et femmes et une grande quantité de céréales pour la restauration. Les habillements sont achetés souvent au Burkina et à Bamako, les céréales et les condiments pour la restauration sont achetés en détail aux environnants et sont revendus au marché de Massigui à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 20 750FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont investis dans la nourriture, dans la santé et dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Badenya group are married women who average 34 years of age and 3 children. They live with their husbands and children in large traditional families in the Massigui village, in the Massigui sub-prefecture, Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali. They got acquainted by links of neighborhood and kinship. They sell various items and do catering, especially on fair days. Eager to have financial support in view of contributing to the family expenses, these women work with Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are seeking their twelfth solidarity loan (group loan). All previous loans were repaid without problem. They intend to use this loan to buy men's and women's clothing, and a large quantity of cereals for their catering business. The clothes are purchased mostly in Burkina Faso and in Bamako, whereas cereals and condiments are purchased from retailers in the surrounding villages. They sell at the Massigui market, to a clientele comprising both men and women. They foresee turning a monthly profit of XOF 20'750 (ca US$ 50) each, to be invested into food, healthcare, and their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing and cereals

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary E. is married and has four children. She has no educational background. Since 2006, Mary has sold food supplies such as tomatoes, pepper, and garden eggs at Elmina near Atoaba. Her husband is a driver. Mary uses her income to help pay school fees and utility bills.

Mary will use the loan to purchase more food supplies for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to save money for reinvestment purposes.

loans.use: To purchase more food supplies for sale.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
For about a year, Fatima Q. has prepared and sold fried yam with fried fish and pepper sauce at Elmina near Atabadzi. Fatima has two children. She has received a junior high education. Fatima uses her income toward the payment of apartment rent and utility bills.

Fatima will use the loan to purchase more yams for use in her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Fatima plans to save to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more yams for use in her food business.

loans.name: Benkola Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkola sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 40 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Massigui, sous préfecture de MASSIGUI, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage, de parentés et font le  commerce d’articles divers et la restauration en vue d’amoindrir les charges de leur mari. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur douzième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter des habillements pour hommes et femmes et une grande quantité de céréales pour la restauration. Les habillements sont achetés aux marchés de Massigui et Dioïla, les céréales et les condiments alimentaires pour la restauration sont achetés en détail aux environnants et sont revendus au marché de Massigui à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 22 000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre la nourriture, la santé et  le réinvestissement dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkola group are married women who average 40 years of age and 4 children. They live with their husbands and children in large traditional families in the Massigui village, in the Massigui sub-prefecture, Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali. They got acquainted by links of neighborhood and kinship, and sell various items and do catering in order to help their husbands with the family expenses. Eager to always have financial support for their businesses, these women work with Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are seeking their twelfth solidarity loan (group loan). All previous loans were repaid without problem. They intend to use this loan to buy men's and women's clothing, and a large quantity of cereals for their catering business. The clothes are purchased at the markets in Massigui and in Dioïla, whereas cereals and condiments are purchased from retailers in the surrounding villages. They sell at the Massigui market, to a clientele comprising both men and women. They foresee turning a monthly profit of XOF 22'000 (ca US$ 50) each, to be divided between providing food and healthcare to their families, and reinvesting into the businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing and cereals

loans.name: Phally

texts.en:
Mrs. Phally S., 39, is widow with two daughters (pictured here with her brother). She lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  Both her daughters are garment factory workers. 

Phally has been a farmer since she was young. She grows corn. Besides of farming, she also sells fruit (mangoes).. She is now requesting her first loan in the amount of $600 to purchase mangoes on contract for resale.

loans.use: To purchase mangoes on contract for resale.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 36 ans et 2 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Massigui, sous préfecture de MASSIGUI, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles  sont liées par des liens de commerce, de parentés et font toutes le commerce d’articles divers en vue d’amoindrir les charges de leur mari. 
Elles viennent de connaitre l’institution grâce à leurs camarades de la place.
Ces femmes ont alors décidé de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire et le premier prêt a été bien remboursé. 
Elles comptent utiliser le nouveau prêt pour  acheter, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires et d’articles divers. Les condiments sont achetés sur le marché de Massigui, quant aux autres produits ils sont achetés en grande partie à Dioïla et Fana et sont revendus au marché de MASSIGUI à une clientèle composée de femmes et    d’hommes.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 26 000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre la nourriture, la santé et  le réinvestissement dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group are married women with an average age of 36 and 2 children, They live with their husband and children in large traditional families in the village of Massigui, in the Massigui prefecture, in the Koulikoro region of the Republic of Mali. They know each other through business and kinship ties and all sell a range of items with a view to reducing their husband’s responsibilities. They learned of the institution through their friends. These women therefore decided to work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in the hope of having a steady income for their businesses.

They are on their second group loan and the first one was repaid correctly. They plan on using the new loan to buy a large quantity of condiments and miscellaneous items. The condiments are purchased from the Massigui market, and the other items are mainly bought in Djoïla and Fana and are resold in the Massigui market to both male and female customers.

Each member expects to earn an average profit of 26,000 FCFA per month. The profits will be shared out between food, health products and reinventing in their businesses.

Translated from French by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments and miscellaneous items

loans.name: Allah Akbar Group

texts.en: Afeelwa is thirty four years old. She is married and has given birth to two children. Both of her children are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Kade. Kade is a farming/commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Afeelwa is a trader. She trades in cereals. She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Allah Akbar’. Most of the group members are either into trading and or farming activities. The group requests a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. Afeelwa, the group leader is seated in the middle in this photograph. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy supplies of cereal for resale

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djiguisseme sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 36 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants, elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Massigui, sous préfecture de MASSIGUI, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles sont liées par des relations de voisinage et de parentés. Elles font le commerce d’articles  divers et la restauration. 
Elles ont connues l’institution à travers les anciennes clientes de la ville, il y’a environ trois ans, dès lors ces femmes également collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir  un appui financier constant pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur huitième prêt  solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter des habillements pour hommes et femmes et une grande quantité de céréales et de condiments alimentaires pour la restauration et beaucoup d’autres articles divers. 
Les habillements sont achetés en grande partie à Bamako et à Fana, les céréales, les condiments alimentaires pour la restauration et les autres articles divers sont achetés en détail aux environnants et sont revendus au marché de Massigui à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 45 600FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre la nourriture,  la santé et  les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Djiguisseme are married women who are an average of 36 years old, with an average of 4 children each. With their husbands and children, they live in large traditional families and reside in the village of Massigui within the subprefecture of Massigui, in the region of Koulikoro, in the Republic of Mali. They are tied together by family and because they live in the same neighborhood. Their business is selling a diverse selection of products, as well as catering. The new of the microfinance institution (Soro Yiriwaso) through former clients in the city. For about three years, these women have collaborated equally with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso for consistent financial support for their businesss. This will be their eighth loan together and all of their previous loans have been fully repaid. With this new loan they intend to purchase clothes for men and women, a large stock of cereals and food products for their restaurand, and a variety of many other items. The clothes will be mostly purchased in Bamako and Fana; the cereals, condiments for the restaurant and various other products will be bought from retailers in the surrounding areas and will be resold in the market of Massigui to a clientele composed of women and men. They estimate that they will each earn a monthly average income of 45,600 FCFA. They will use their earnings to purchase food, health products and for activities.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a variety of items

loans.name: High Society Group

texts.en: Justice is forty years old. He is divorced and has two children. Both of his children are in school. He lives with his children in a rented apartment in Kade. Kade is a farming/commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Justice is a trader. He trades in palm oil. He is the leader of a trust bank group called High Society. Most of the group members are either into trading or farming activities. The group requests a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. Justice, the group leader is seated in the photograph. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy supplies of palm oil for resale

loans.name: Nadezhda

texts.en:
Nadezhda sells jeans clothing at Voznesenovski market in Zaporozhye. Nadezhda is divorced. She started this business 12 years ago. Being very open and friendly Nadezhda has provided superior customer service and has gained many clients. Today, she has two business locations and offersa large assortment of good jeans and clothing to her repeated and new clients.

Nadezhda would like to borrow 11,300 UAH to purchase more inventory. She would like to increase her sales and develop her business further.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory

loans.name: Kotognongontala Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Kotognongontala sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 36 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Massigui, sous préfecture de MASSIGUI, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parentés et font le commerce d’articles divers et la restauration. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur douzième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents  se sont bien dénoués. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter des habillements pour hommes et femmes et une grande quantité de céréales et de condiments alimentaires pour la restauration. Les habillements sont achetés en grande partie à Bamako et à Fana, les céréales et les condiments alimentaires pour la restauration sont achetés en détail dans les villages environnants et sont revendus  au marché de Massigui à une clientèle  diverse et variée.  
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 39 000FCFA  par mois qui sera utilisé  dans la nourriture, dans la santé et dans l’activité proprement dite.
texts.en:
The members of the group Kotognongontala are married women, they are 36 years ols on average and have an average of 3 children each. They live with their husbands and children in large, traditional families in the village of Massigui, which is within the subprefecture of Massigui, in the region of Koulikoro, in the Republic of Mali. These women know each other through neighborhood and familial connections. Their business is selling various items and catering. The women have been working with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso for financial support for their business activities. They are on their twelfth loan together and all of their prior loans have all been properly repaid. They will use the new loan to purchase clothes for men and women, a large quantity of grains/ cereals and condiments for their restaurant business. The clothes will be purchased in large part in Bamako and in Fana, whereas the grains and condiments for their restaurant will be purchased at retail from the surrounding towns, and will be resold in the market of Massigui to a diverse and varied clientele. They hope to each earn an average monthly profit of 39,000 FCFA, which they will use for food, for health expenses and for their aforementioned business activities.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a variety of items

loans.name: Ahemaa Group

texts.en: Victoria is forty five years old. She is married and has given birth to three children. All of her children are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Kade. Kade is a farming/commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Victoria is a trader. She trades in printed textile materials. She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Ahemaa ’, meaning queens. Most of the group members are either into trading or farming activities. The group requests a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. Victoria, the group leader is in the middle of the photograph. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy supplies of printed textile material

loans.name: Shahlo

texts.en:
Shahlo D. is 25 years old and married. Surrounded by beautiful and tame cows on pasture land, Shahlo carries out her daily work herding the grazing cattle. She has been dedicated to this occupation for the last 6 years. Her husband works as cleaning staff at the local center. Both work very hard to support and education their dearest children. Shahlo wishes to give each of them the opportunity of superior education. She wishes to buy calves for breeding and reproduction and is therefore asking for a loan of $1500 USD. Let us help this industrious woman to achieve her dreams .    


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase calves in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sabougnouma sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 36 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Massigui, sous préfecture de MASSIGUI, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parentés. 
Elles font le commerce d’articles divers et la restauration. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter des habillements pour hommes et femmes et une grande quantité de céréales pour la restauration. Le plus souvent, elles partent acheter les habits en gros à Bamako et à Fana,  les céréales sont achetées en détail aux environnants et sont revendus au marché de Massigui à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 37 500FCFA  par mois qui sera utilisé  dans la nourriture, la santé et dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Sabougnouma are married women, on average they are 36 years old and each have an average of 3 children. With their husbands and children, they live in large, traditional families and are residents of the village of Massigui, in the subprefecture of Massigui, within the region of Koulikoro, in the Republic of Mali. They know each other through neighborhood and familial connections. Their business is selling varied items and catering. These women have worked with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to have consistent financial support for their business actvities. They are on their third group loan and all of their previous loans have been properly repaid. They will use this loan to purchase clothes for men and women, as well as a large quantity of grains/ cereals for their food business. Usually they buy their clothes at wholesale prices from Bamako and in Fana, they purchase the grains from the surrounding areas and will resell these products in the market of Massigui to a clientele composed of men and women. They estimate that with will each earn an average monthly income of 37,500FCFA, which they will use to purchase food, for their health and their business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a variety of items

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph E. S. is married and has four children. He has received a senior highschool education.  Joseph is a pharmacist who sells both locally made and imported drugs at Elmina, which he has been doing since 1999. His wife is a small trader.  Joseph uses his income to pay school fees and utility bills. Joseph will use the loan to purchase more drugs to sell. With the new profits from his expanded business, Joseph plans to save and reinvest.

loans.use: Joseph will use the loan to purchase more drugs to sell.

loans.name: Trinity Group

texts.en: Lydia is twenty seven years old. She is married and has given birth to three children. All of her children are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Kade. Kade is a farming/commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Lydia is a trader. She runs a provision store. She is the leader of a trust bank group called Trinity. Most of the group members are either into trading or farming activities. The group requests a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. Lydia, the group leader is standing in the photograph. It is their desire to give their children the best  education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy grocery supplies for her store

loans.name: Jehova Grace Group

texts.en: Emmanuel is forty one years old. He is married and has three children. All of his children are in school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in Kade. Kade is a farming/commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. He is a trader. He runs a provision store. Emmanuel is the leader of a trust bank group called Jehovah Grace. Most of the group members are either into trading or farming activities. The group requests a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. Emmanuel, the group leader is second from the left in the photograph. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy supplies for his store

loans.name: Azizbek

texts.en:
K. Azizbek is 22 years old. For more than 4 years he has been selling DVD's and CD's. He works in the market. Azizbek orders the delivery of the disks from Russia and tries to have all new movies, concerts of the popular singers etc. The business is successful and generates the main income for the family. Today Azizbek requests $800 US Dollars to purchase the lot of DVD's, CD's for resale. Azizbek thanks all those supporting him and promises to meet his loan payments.
